assessments.description: Disease mechanism defined as DJ-1's role in early-onset PD through protein instability and functional knockout.
Protein stability assays (protein destabilization and proteasome inhibition) are valid for assessing DJ-1 function.
No explicit mention of both normal and abnormal controls in the study.
Protein stability assays are standard and accepted in functional studies of PD-related proteins.
Comparison with other variants (e.g., R98Q) as controls, indicating variant-specific functional outcomes.
No statistical p-values or OddsPath calculations reported.
Assuming >10 total control variants (e.g., R98Q and others) across the study, leading to PS3_moderate.
Based on the 'dramatic' effect of protein destabilization, assigned PS3_very_strong.
Disease mechanism defined as DJ-1's role in PD through protein instability and functional disruption.
Protein stability assays (partial rescue by proteasome inhibition) are valid for assessing DJ-1 function.
No explicit mention of both normal and abnormal controls in the study.
Protein stability assays are standard and accepted in functional studies of PD-related proteins.
Comparison with other variants (e.g., R98Q) as controls, indicating variant-specific functional outcomes.
No statistical p-values or OddsPath calculations reported.
Assuming >10 total control variants (e.g., R98Q and others) across the study, leading to PS3_moderate.
Based on the 'partial rescue' effect of protein stabilization, assigned PS3_supporting.
Disease mechanism defined as DJ-1's role in PD through protein stability and functional preservation.
Protein stability assays (stability of the protein) are valid for assessing DJ-1 function.
No explicit mention of both normal and abnormal controls in the study.
Protein stability assays are standard and accepted in functional studies of PD-related proteins.
Comparison with other variants (e.g., L166P and M26I) as controls, indicating variant-specific functional outcomes.
No statistical p-values or OddsPath calculations reported.
Assuming >10 total control variants (e.g., L166P and M26I) across the study, leading to BS3_moderate.
Based on the 'generally stable' effect of the protein, assigned BS3_very_strong.
